thread.title: Loveland softball has its terrific season come to a shocking end at regionals
thread.title_full: Loveland softball has its terrific season come to a shocking end at regionals

author:
Sean Star 

Reporter-Herald Sports Writer
title: Loveland softball has its terrific season come to a shocking end at regionals
text:
Loveland softball has its terrific season come to a shocking end at regionals Out-of-charter Indians fall in 10 innings to Eaglecrest in state qualifying game By Sean Star 
Reporter-Herald Sports Writer Posted: 10/17/2015 08:25:19 PM MDT Loveland pitcher Abby Lukkes threw 22 of the 24 innings the Indians played Saturday at the 5A Region 7 tournament at Barnes Complex, where the team's terrific season came to a sudden end. ( Trevor L Davis / Loveland Reporter-Herald ) 
The city of Loveland didn't need another reminder of just how cruel softball regionals can be, but it got one anyway. 
A year after Mountain View failed to make it to state following a stellar regular season, Loveland suffered the same fate Saturday at Barnes Complex. 
The Indians — who went 16-3 in the regular season and finished with just one loss in a Front Range League that has five teams going to state — saw their otherwise terrific 2015 campaign come to a gut-wrenching end with a 10-7 loss in 10 innings to Eaglecrest in the 5A Region 7 state qualifying game. 
"It's very frustrating, especially coming into this 16-3 and just not showing up to play," said LHS center fielder Tatum Rembao, who was 2-for-4 with a double and an inside-the-park home run in the season-ending loss. "That's not like us at all. We just weren't ready to play and it kinda bit us in the butt." 
From the start it just wasn't the Indians' day as the hosts opened the tournament by striking out 16 times in a stunning 12-3 loss to No. 26 seed Chatfield, a team that went just 8-11 in the regular season but went on to win the regional title with a wild 13-11 win over Eaglecrest. 
The seventh-seeded Indians rebounded to keep their season alive with a 10-4 win over No. 23 Mountain Vista, boosted by a seven-run fourth sparked by Macey King's two-run homer, followed later by a two-run double by Rembao. Advertisement 
It looked like the Indians would for sure get a rematch with Chatfield, but the Chargers pulled off a dramatic seventh-inning comeback to win the regional title, setting up the qualifying game with 10th-seeded Eaglecrest. 
A run-scoring double by Kassi Reiger followed by a two-run homer by Jessi Case put the Indians up 3-0 after two. LHS then stretched its lead to 5-1 in the third with two-run single by Abby Lukkes, and at that time it appeared the Indians had successfully bounced back and were ready to punch their ticket to state. 
However, a pitching change in the third by Eaglecrest quieted the Indians' bats as Kathleen Ingram came in and gave up just two runs on three hits in 7 2/3 innings to earn the win. 
Meanwhile the Raptors offensive slowly got going against Lukkes, who threw 22 of the 24 innings her team played Saturday. Eaglecrest scratched across two each in the fourth and fifth and another to tie it in the sixth, the fourth unearned run allowed by the normally sure-gloved Indians. 
Loveland had its chances to win it late, mainly the seventh when Rembao led off with a double but was stranded there. In the eighth both King and Reiger were on with two outs when a hard-hit grounder by Addi Woodard was mishandled by the Eaglecrest shortstop, appearing to set the Indians up with the bases loaded; but runner interference was called on King to end the threat. First baseman Addi Woodard takes a swing during her team's loss to Chatfield on Saturday. ( Trevor L Davis / Loveland Reporter-Herald ) 
LHS went down in order in both the ninth and 10th, and in between, the Raptors scored three runs aided by three LHS errors to claim the trip to state. 
"It was a weird day. We played great for five and a half weeks, and you have a bad day of softball," Loveland coach Mike Felton said. "No. 28 winning the region, and then 7 and 10 playing for a consolation. The way (Eaglecrest) lost the game before us, or else we would've been playing Chatfield. It was a weird day. That's why you play the game." 
The only silver lining for the Indians is that all but one of their players returns next season, with senior catcher Braxton Morby the loss. 
Mountain View was able to exorcise its demons from last year this year, so perhaps Loveland can do the same in 2016. 
"To end it like this is really awful. I think next season we're going to learn from it and we're going to come back from it. I really hope that we do," said Reiger, who had a tremendous diving catch in left field in the loss to Chatfield. 
"But, it happens. You get one day to be on, and we weren't on. Next year we have to know you've got to come to play that one day and advance to state." 
Sean Star: 970-669-5050, sstar@reporter-herald.com or twitter.com/seanvstar 
5A Region 7 State Qualifying Game 
At Barnes Complex 
Eaglecrest 001 321 0003 — 10 14 1 
Loveland 032 200 0000 — 7 9 6 
W — Kathleen Ingram. L — Abby Lukkes. 
Eaglecrest hitting (ab-r-h-rbi) — Chelsea Gorman 5-1-3-1, Brandee Morris 5-2-1-0, Alexa Romero 5-1-1-1, Kailey Wilson 3-2-2-3, Tayler Mashburn 5-0-2-0, Sarah Bushman 3-0-0-0, Kathleen Ingram 3-1-1-0, Braelyne Crenshaw 6-1-1-0, Rachel Sabourin 5-1-2-2, Destynee Morgan 6-1-1-0. Totals 46-10-14-7. 2B — Wilson. 
Loveland hitting (ab-r-h-rbi) — Tatum Rembao 4-2-2-1, Blair Bernhardt 4-1-0-0, Braxton Morby 5-0-0-0, Abby Lukkes 5-0-1-2, Wendy Dykstra 5-1-2-0, Macey King 4-0-0-0, Kassi Reiger 4-1-2-1, Jessi Case 4-2-2-2, Addi Woodard 3-0-0-1. Totals 43-9-7-7. 2B — Rembao, Reiger. HR — Rembao. SB — Rembao 2, Reiger, Case. 
Eaglescrest pitching (ip-h-r-er-bb-so) — Bushman 2.1-5-5-5-2-0, Ingram 7.2-4-2-1-1-5. 
Loveland pitching (ip-h-r-er-bb-so) — Lukkes 10-14-10-6-6-5.
